data.title: The United Nations Club at Hawai'i Pacific
data.text:
Megan Jensen, President

(B.A. Political Science and International Studies)

Megan is attending HPU on a Debate Society scholarship and is a active member of the Debate Society in addition to being President of the UN Club. She was born in Arizona and has since lived in Oregon, Alaska, Nevada, and Washington State. Megan was appointed as a United States Senate Page under Senator Harry Reid of Nevada during the fall semester of 2007. During the spring semester of 2010 she served as a 2010 legislative intern for Senator Les Ihara Jr at the Hawai`i State Capitol. She is currently working as a student management program assistant for the Federal Highway Administration office located in Honolulu.

Megan is a member of Alpha Lambda Delta Honor Society, STAND and is currently serving as a HPU President's Host.

She is looking forward to a new year, with a completely new e-board and is excited to see where the UN Club is headed.

Jamelee Bal, Vice President

(B.A. Diplomacy & Military Studies)

Jamelee has been an active member of the United Nations Association of Sweden since 2006, participated in Youth Congresses and the UNESCO sponsored culture project in Turkey 2007. Jamelee's passion for international relations primarily comes from her personal background. She was born in Istanbul, has origins from Bulgaria, and grew up in Sweden. Her interest areas are international relations, human rights and linguistics. Jamelee is enrolled in the B.A. Diplomacy & Military Studies program at Hawai'i Pacific University and a member of Alpha Lambda Delta Honor Society.

Yasemin Karabudak, Treasurer

Born and raised in Germany, Yasemin still identifies with her Turkish heritage. Her multicultural background and open-minded personality make it easy for her to be approachable and interested to other cultures and languages. She took different language classes over the years for example Latin, Spanish, and Japanese and is also fluent in German, Turkish, English and French. Having been able to get different impressions of the United States amongst others Washington, California and Hawaii as an exchange student in 2006 was a tremendous help for her to decide what she would like to do in her future career, studying international relations and becoming a diplomat for the United Nations. In her Freshman year she served as the Freshman Senator in the Student Government Association and got her first experiences as a Treasurer in the German Speaking Student Association.

Tracy Chorro, Secretary

(Nursing Program, Minor International Studies)

Dr Grace Cheng, Faculty Adviser

(Ph.D. Political Science, M.A. Asian Studies)

Dr. Cheng is the selected club advisor, who teaches courses in political science, Vietnam and China, the Practicum for the International Relations/Studies majors, and current international topics such as human rights and ethnic conflict. These interests led her to being the adviser of the club. Cheng's research focuses on reform in Vietnam and China, as well as cross-cultural perspectives on human rights. During the summer of 1998 she facilitated a series of panels on cultural change at the First International Conference on Vietnamese Studies in Hanoi, Vietnam. Summer of 1999 she returned to Hanoi to coordinate the Short Term Program for Vietnamese History and Society for college-level educators.

In 2002, Dr. Cheng received a National Endowment to the Humanities Fellowship to study The Impact of Islam on State Formation and Societal Transformation. She attended the University of Chicago summer program and launched courses on "Islam and Politics," "International Law," and "Islam and Terrorism" at HPU. She has participated in many professional programs, including the NEH sponsored program at Eckerd College in Florida on Asian Studies, and a program at Peking University in China in 2001. For her hard work in the scientific community she won the Fulbright-Hays Grant for programs in Vietnam in 1999. She has also been awarded the Henry Luce Award; Pacific Asian Scholarship, at University of Hawai'i Manoa, where she earned her doctor of philosophy and master of arts. Dr. Cheng is fluent in Chinese, and earned a Bachelors degree in Chinese at Georgetown University.

Dr. Cheng is a strong supporter of the UN Declaration of Human Rights and advises both the UN Club at HPU and Amnesty International at HPU.
